expectedResults.title: Cross-Site Scripting in Image Source
expectedResults.reason: The expected XSS vulnerability in the xss20 endpoint (lines 66-67 of app.py) was not successfully identified. While the penetration test did discover that the /xss20 endpoint exists and returns HTTP 500 errors, the actual XSS vulnerability involving unsafe insertion of user input into an img src attribute was not detected or reported. The HTTP 500 error may have prevented proper testing of the XSS payload, or the testing methodology did not include XSS-specific payloads that bypass the character filtering mentioned in the expected finding.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers - Clickjacking Vulnerability
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate security finding representing a new discovery. The absence of security headers (X-Frame-Options, CSP, HSTS, X-XSS-Protection, X-Content-Type-Options) is a real vulnerability that increases the application's attack surface, particularly for clickjacking and MIME-sniffing attacks. This is not a false positive.

actualResults.title: ETag Header Information Disclosure
actualResults.location: Static file server (/static/css/style.css and other static resources)
actualResults.assessment: This is a valid information disclosure finding, though low severity. The ETag header exposes file metadata (timestamp, size, hash) that could aid reconnaissance. This is a legitimate security concern, not a false positive, though the risk is minimal.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure via HTTP 500 Error on /xss20 Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: This is a legitimate finding about improper error handling and information disclosure through server headers. Interestingly, this finding indicates the tester reached the xss20 endpoint where the expected XSS vulnerability exists, but the HTTP 500 error prevented discovery of the actual XSS issue. The finding itself is valid regarding error handling, but it also suggests the XSS vulnerability may be masked by implementation errors.

actualResults.title: Outdated and End-of-Life Software Components
actualResults.assessment: This is a critical and legitimate security finding. The use of Python 2.7 (EOL since 2020) and outdated Werkzeug with known CVEs (CVE-2023-25577, CVE-2023-23934) represents a significant security risk. This is definitely not a false positive and should be addressed urgently.

actualResults.title: Werkzeug Development Server in Production
actualResults.assessment: This is a valid security misconfiguration finding. Running a development server in production exposes the application to performance issues, DoS vulnerabilities, and lacks security hardening. This is a legitimate concern and not a false positive.
